fields.name: All-or-Nothing Thinking
fields.explanation: You see things in black-and-white categories. If your performance falls short of perfect, you see yourself as a total failure.
fields.tip: Practice seeing the gray areas and spectrum in outcomes, not just the extremes.

fields.name: Overgeneralization
fields.explanation: You see a single negative event as a never-ending pattern of defeat.
fields.tip: Challenge this thought by finding evidence against the pattern.

fields.name: Mental Filter
fields.explanation: You pick out a single negative detail and dwell on it exclusively, so that your vision of reality becomes darkened.
fields.tip: Actively acknowledge and consider the positive aspects of a situation as well.

fields.name: Disqualifying the Positive
fields.explanation: You reject positive experiences by insisting they 'don't count' for some reason or another.
fields.tip: Consciously accept positive experiences and achievements, acknowledging their value.

fields.name: Jumping to Conclusions
fields.explanation: You make a negative interpretation even though there are no definite facts that convincingly support your conclusion.
fields.tip: Challenge your conclusions by looking for evidence that contradicts them.

fields.name: Magnification or Minimization
fields.explanation: You exaggerate the importance of things (such as your goof-up or someone else's achievement), or you inappropriately shrink things until they appear tiny.
fields.tip: Practice viewing situations with balanced importance, not distorting them.

fields.name: Emotional Reasoning
fields.explanation: You assume that your negative emotions necessarily reflect the way things really are: 'I feel it, therefore it must be true.'
fields.tip: Distinguish between feelings and facts. Challenge the assumption that emotions reflect reality.

fields.name: Should Statements
fields.explanation: You try to motivate yourself with shoulds and shouldn'ts, as if you had to be whipped and punished before you could be expected to do anything.
fields.tip: Replace 'should' statements with 'would like to' to reduce self-imposed pressure.

fields.name: Labeling and Mislabeling
fields.explanation: This is an extreme form of overgeneralization. Instead of describing your error, you attach a negative label to yourself.
fields.tip: Identify and challenge the labels. Define yourself by your actions, not by mistakes or oversimplifications.

fields.name: Personalization
fields.explanation: You see yourself as the cause of some negative external event for which, in fact, you were not primarily responsible.
fields.tip: Recognize that not everything that happens around you is your fault or within your control.
